context:
patient_presentation: A 57-year-old woman with a history of multiple ventral hernia mesh repairs, with the most recent hernia repair 2 years ago, and a nonhealing gastric ulcer for the past 8 months (Figure A, white arrow) presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, swelling, and redness in the midabdomen for the past 3 days.
imaging_without_photo: A fistulogram did not show any communication with the stomach or small bowel.
imaging_test_with_photo: ...and a nonhealing gastric ulcer for the past 8 months (Figure A, white arrow)...
next_imaging: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen showed prior ventral abdominal wall hernia mesh repair with development of an abscess within the subcutaneous tissues of the anterior abdominal wall (Figure B, red arrow) in addition to a possible intra-abdominal fistulous communication where the stomach abuts the anterior abdominal wall (Figures B and C, blue arrow).
third_imaging: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a 25-mm cratered gastric ulcer with evidence of mesh eroding through the anterior gastric wall (Figure D, black arrow).
diagnosis: ...mesh eroding through the anterior gastric wall....Mesh migration...

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old woman with history of irritable bowel syndrome and recurrent Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis presented with recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain.
additional_history: She was hospitalized three times in the past year with C. diff colitis. To treat her C. diff colitis, she had completed two courses of oral metronidazole and one course of oral vancomycin. In addition, she completed EGD with fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) with duodenal instillation. After referral to our gastroenterology clinic, she was started on a vancomycin pulse-taper dose and rifaximin with diarrhea improvement. Three months later, she underwent colonoscopy with FMT for diarrhea recurrence. Soon after colonoscopy with FMT, she was hospitalized again with characteristic abdominal pain and severe diarrhea.
initial_laboratory_results: Basic bloodwork was unremarkable. C. diff studies were negative.
imaging_test_with_photo: Abdominal CT at that time showed marked wall thickening, inflammatory stranding, and irregularity of distal ascending, transverse, and proximal descending colon, and small ascites (Fig. A).
next_imaging: Abdominal CT during this episode revealed severe focal bowel thickening and edema involving the duodenum and proximal jejunum, as well as ascites. Unlike the prior episode, there was no evidence of colonic thickening (Fig. B).
diagnosis: Symptoms spontaneously resolved, but three months later she was again readmitted wtih acute diffuse, crampy abdominal pain, with associated nausea with emesis and diarrhea. C. diff studies were again negative. Abdominal CT during this episode revealed severe focal bowel thickening and edema involving the duodenum and proximal jejunum, as well as ascites.

context:
patient_presentation: A 60-year-old woman with pancreatic adenocarcinoma presented with severe nausea and vomiting, with suspicion of malignant gastroduodenal obstruction by the mass. 
additional_history: She underwent an emergent endoscopy that showed a duodenal stricture, which was dilated and stented. Shortly thereafter, the patient complained of severe abdominal pain and had voluntary guarding wtih peritoneal signs on physical examination.
imaging_test_with_photo: A supine radiograph was obtained and showed air on both sides of the intestinal wall, consistent with pneumoperitoneum (Figure A). This radiographic finding is known as the Rigler or double wall sign, which is particularly useful on supine imaging. However, this must be distinguished from the false double wall sign, which refers to 2 dilated loops of bowel in close apposition to one another, which may be mistaken for free air.
next_imaging: The patient underwent computed tomography that confirmed the pneumoperitoneum (Figure B), which was caused by a perforation of the duodenum by the stent. Subphrenic air also was seen (Figure B, arrowheads).
diagnosis: Pneumoperitoneum (Rigler or double wall sign)

context:
patient_presentation: A 63-year-old woman with a history of cervical carcinoma status post resection, radiation, and a diverting sigmoid colostomy was evaluated for episodic abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and 100-lb weight loss.
physical_exam: Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 103/57 mm Hg, pulse of 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 16, and temperature of 36.8°C. Her abdomen was distended and tender to palpation without rebound or guarding.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory evaluation revealed a high white blood cell count of 14,500 per cubic millimeter, creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen of 31 mg/dL, and low potassium of 2.5 mmol/L.
imaging_test_with_photo: A noncontrast computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis showed herniation of a large portion of the distal stomach into a left lower quadrant parastomal hernia with the herniated stomach being moderately distended, in comparison with the massively dilated intra-abdominal stomach (Figure A and B).
next_imaging: The patient was taken to the operating room where she underwent relief of gastric obstruction and repair of the parastomal hernia with colostomy revision (Figure C and D).
diagnosis: ...herniation of a large portion of the distal stomach into a left lower quadrant parastomal hernia with the herniated stomach being moderately distended, in comparison with the massively dilated intra-abdominal stomach.

context:
patient_presentation: A 62-year-old woman was admitted because of melena.
physical_exam: On physical examination, her vital signs were normal and her conjunctiva was anemic.
initial_laboratory_results:  Laboratory data showed a hemoglobin level of 6.1 g/dL....
imaging_without_photo: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography showed a well-defined hypervascular mass wtih a central low-density area in the first section of the duodenum.
imaging_test_with_photo: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a pedunculated polypoid lesion arising from the pyloric ring (Figure A).
next_imaging: A barium study showed a large filling defect in the first section of the duodenum, and its surface was slightly lobular (Figure B).
third_imaging: She underwent distal gastrectomy for removal of this large lesion (Figure C).
diagnosis: A pathologic diagnosis of Brunner's gland hamartoma (BGH) was made.

context:
patient_presentation: A 52-year-old man with myelofibrosis presented to the emergency room with hematemesis. 
additional_history: Earlier that day, he had experienced cough, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. On the evening of admission, he vomited blood, prompting him to seek medical attention. He denied fevers, chills, chest pain, abdominal pain, melena, hematochezia, prior history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug ingestion, or alcohol abuse. He was afebrile and hemodynamically stable.
physical_exam: Physical examination was significant for splenomegaly and brown, guaiac-positive stool. His abdomen was nontender and nondistended without overt evidence of hepatomegaly.
initial_laboratory_results: Pertinent laboratory results were as follows: blood urea nitrogen, 34 mg/dL; International Normalized Ratio, 1.3; white blood cell count 4.6 K/μL; platelets, 194 K/μL; and hemoglobin, 12.5 g/dL, which decreased to 9.6 g/dL on repeat 6 hours later.
imaging_test_with_photo: An urgent upper endoscopy revealed isolated gastric varices with recent evidence of bleeding (Figure A, yellow arrow).
diagnosis: On presentation, he was given an intravenous bolus of esomeprazole 80 mg and initiated on an intravenous esomeprazole drip at 8 mg/h....He was given a bolus of intravenous octreotide 50 mg followed by an intravenous octreotide drip at 50 mg/h and ceftriaxone 1 g/d. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for further monitoring.

context:
patient_presentation: An 82-year-old man was referred to the gastroenterology outpatient department on the fast-track cancer pathway with iron-deficiency anemia and melena. 
additional_history: Sixteen months previously the patient had a mycotic saccular aneurysm of the distal descending thoracic aorta repaired using an endovascular stent graft (Valiant Captivia Thoracic Stent Graft; Medtronic, Minneapolis, MN). Long-term flucloxacillin was commenced because blood cultures taken during stent grafting grew Staphylococcus aureus. He was considered unfit for surgery.
physical_exam: His clinical examination was normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Hemoglobin, 87 g/L; mean corpuscular volume, 68.8
imaging_test_with_photo: He was referred for ugent gastroscopy and computed tomography (CT) colonography. Gastroscopy showed a potentially fungating mass protruding into the posterior wall of the esophagus (Figure A). Wires were visible on the surface of the mass, suggesting that the patient's endovascular stent had eroded into the esophagus. Remaining gastroscopy showed only occasional erosions and CT colonography was normal.
next_imaging: Eight months after the repair, the patient had an episode of chest pain with pyrexia, hypotension, and possible hematemesis. CT intially reported no abnormality of the stent graft repair and the patient was treated for angina. In light of the endoscopy findings, the CT scan was re-reviewed at the multidisciplinary meeting, and in retrospect a small defect in the esophageal wall adjacent to the stent graft was identified (Figure B, the row of arrowheads denotes the location of the stent graft, the white arrow points to air within the distal esophagus).
third_imaging: A further CT scan performed 3 weeks after endoscopy showed gas surrounding the stent graft. Absent previously, the gas confirmed the presence of an aorto-esophageal fistula (AEF) (Figure C, the radio-opaque struts of the stent graft are marked at SG, the white arrow points to air within the esophagus and to the defect in the esophageal wall, the arrowhead points to air between the aortic wall and wall of the stent graft).
diagnosis: Absent previously, the gas confirmed the presence of an aorto-esophageal fistula (AEF)...

context:
patient_presentation: A 73-year-old male underwent screening colonoscopy. 
additional_history: He has lived for a couple of years in Namibia on his farm and has gone several times on hunting safaris in other African countries. He was not aware of any serious diseases in the past except for fever for 2–3 days and a rash on his back and chest during one of his safaris in Zambia. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Colonoscopy was performed on an outpatient basis and documented normal findings except for a 2-cm mass in the distal sigmoid with a normal-appearing mucosa on narrow band imaging (Figure A, B).

patient_presentation: A 63-year-old man with Barrett’s esophagus (C5M6) with multifocal high-grade dysplasia and residual esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) despite multiple endoscopic mucosal resections sought a non-surgical treatment.
imaging_without_photo: We utilized advanced imaging along with volumetric laser endomicroscopy (VLE) to delineate the extent of dysplasia and cancer to determine resection margin. Consequently, circumferential endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) of the distal 9 cm was successfully performed to the gastric cardia.
imaging_test_with_photo: The utility of computer-enhanced VLE was explored. VLE was performed prior to ESD, processed with an offline prototype algorithm (NinePoint Medical, Bedford, MA) and reconstructed into en-face (B) and endoscopic fly-through (C) views that closely resembled the ex-vivo specimen and EGD image (D). The algorithm also highlighted features previously associated with suspected dysplasia, including hyper-reflective tissue surface signal (orange), hypo-reflective cystic structures above the submucosal layer (pink), and loss of layered architecture (blue). These features clustered together over areas of dysplasia and cancer. Computer-enhanced VLE could potentially aid in delineating high-grade dysplasia and cancer in vivo as an adjunctive imaging modality.
diagnosis: ...views that closely resembled the ex-vivo specimen and EGD image.

context:
patient_presentation: A 49-year-old man, without any medical history, underwent an 18F-fluoro-deoxy-glucose positron emission tomography (18F-FDG-PET) to explore an asthenia that had appeared for 3 months, to eliminate neoplasia. 
additional_history: A diffuse duodenojejunal accumulation of 18F-FDG with a standard uptake value (SUV) at 5.6 was observed. The patient was referred to the gastroenterology department.
physical_exam: Physical examination simply revealed old and minimal digestive symptoms, essentially bloating.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory studies showed antitransglutaminase antibodies positive to 14 U/mL (N <7 U/mL). 
imaging_test_with_photo: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and small bowel capsule endoscopy revealed a duodenojejunal villous atrophy (Figure A).
next_imaging: After 18 months, a new 18F-FDG-PET was performed. The comparison of the initial imagery (Figure C) with the new PET/CT (Figure D) revealed a regression of duodenojejunal FDG uptake from SUV 5.6 to 3.4, with an SUV considered normal at 2.9, corresponding to the hepatic SUV, similar on these 2 PET/CT.
diagnosis: ...the diagnosis of Crohn's disease...

context:
patient_presentation: A 34-year-old woman presented due to falls, weakness, and new-onset jaundice.
physical_exam: Examination demonstrated mild encephalopathy and scleral icterus.
initial_laboratory_results: Liver enzymes indicated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 259 U/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 76 U/L, total bilirubin 9.9 mg/dL, and INR 1.6.
diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with acute on chronic liver disease secondary to alcoholic hepatitis (AH).

context:
patient_presentation: A 54-year-old woman presented to the Emergency Department with symptoms of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain, obstipation, and vomiting).
physical_exam: On clinical examination, there was abdominal distention, increased intestinal sounds, and painful deep palpation of the abdomen.
imaging_test_with_photo: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen was suggestive of intussusception, resulting from an intramural small intestinal tumor (Figure A). An exploratory laparotomy confirmed the presence of the tumor.
next_imaging: Grossly, the tumor was well circumscribed, nonencapsulated, and measured 2.1 cm (Figure B). The adjacent intestinal wall had dark discoloration owing to hemorrhagic necrosis.
diagnosis: The histologic findings of this case are those of a calcifying fibrous tumor, which is a rare benign lesion that can be observed in any location and has been implicated in small intestinal intussusception.

context:
patient_presentation: A 75-year-old man was referred to our hospital with persistent diarrhea.
additional_history: He had a habit of eating raw salmon, although he did not eat raw meat. 
initial_laboratory_results: In laboratory testing, eosinophilia (2232/μL; normal range, 100-300/μL) was detected. 
imaging_without_photo: Abnormal findings were not observed on computed tomography.
imaging_test_with_photo: A flat creamy-white worm with numerous tile-like proglottides was found at the ileocecal valve by colonoscopy (Figures A and B).
next_imaging: A decision was made to inject gastrointestinal contrast medium (Gastrografin; Nihon-Schering, Osaka, Japan) into the worm by antegrade double-balloon enteroscopy (DBE). DBE showed the worm had bitten the jejunal mucosa (Figure C).
third_imaging: Gastrografin was injected directly into the worm through DBE, and the scolex of the worm was removed. The discharge of the worm into the transverse colon was observed under fluroscopic imaging (Video 1). Twelve hours after disinfestation, the fecal discharge of the worm including the scolex was confirmed (Figure D).
diagnosis: Part of the worm was sampled, and it was identified as Diphyllobothrium nihonkaiense.

context:
patient_presentation: A 78-year-old woman with a history of chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection presented to the hospital with a skin rash, diffuse arthralgias, and weakness.
imaging_test_with_photo: Physical examination showed a diffuse palpable purpuric rash (Figures A-C).
next_imaging: Doppler examination showed an absence of perfusion, requiring amputation of the distal part of the fifth digit (Figure D).
diagnosis: ...consistent with type II mixed cryoglobulinemia.

context:
patient_presentation: A 63-year-old man presented with atrial fibrillation and hematemesis. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Chest CT revealed esophageal rupture and oral contrast extravasation (A). Chest tubes were placed but surgical repair was not feasible due to comorbidities and high location of perforation in the thorax due to hiatal hernia.
next_imaging: EGD demonstrated a 2.5 cm perforation with a pulsatile vbisceral surface protruding into the esophageal lumen. Insufflation displaced the lumen away from suspected pericardium (B).
third_imaging: CT imaging confirmed connection to the pericardium at the perforation (C).
diagnosis: CT imaging confirmed connection to the pericardium at the perforation.

context:
patient_presentation: A 62-year-old man with long-standing esophageal reflux underwent endoscopy at an outside institution that reported multiple polypoid lesions in the upper esophagus and a small focal area of nodular mucosa at the gastroesophageal junction.
additional_history: Biopsy specimens of the proximal esophageal polyps showed hyperplastic mucosa with ulceration, reactive epithelial changes, and focal intestinal metaplasia. Biopsy specimens from the nodular gastroesophageal junction mucosa were described as Barrett's esophagus with low-grade dysplasia....The patient underwent endoscopic mucosal resection using a multiband mucosectomy technique.
imaging_test_with_photo: An upper endoscopy performed at our medical center found multiple semipedunculated esophageal polyps between 18 and 24 cm from the incisors (Figure A).
next_imaging: Edosonographically, the polypoid lesions were confined to the mucosa with normal underlying wall layers (Figure B).
diagnosis: The impression of the gastrointestinal pathologists was a hyperplastic polyp with foveolar dysplasia.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old woman presented with multiple episodes of melena and a 5 g/mL decrease in hemoglobin level over a 6-month period.
imaging_without_photo: Three esophagogastroduodenoscopices and 2 colonoscopies were unremarkable. A capsule showed blood in the duodenum without an obvious source. Repeat upper endoscopy showed blood from the major papilla. Further studies were obtained including computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging/magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, endoscopic ultrasound, bleeding scan, and an angiography--all were unremarkable. The decision was made to proceed with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography....Biliary and pancreatic sphincterotomies were performed. No ulcers, arteriovenous malformations, or mass lesions were seen at the exposed ampullary tissue.
imaging_test_with_photo: During the endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography, fresh blood was seen from the ampullary orifice (Figure A). 
next_imaging: After placement of a pancreatic stent, continued bleeding was identified from the ampullary tissue consistent with an ampullary Dieulafoy (Figure B).
third_imaging: The area was cauterized successfully with a bipolar circumactive probe without evidence of further bleeding (Figure C; Supplementary Video 1).
diagnosis: ...consistent with an ampullary Dieulafoy.

context:
patient_presentation: A 55-year-old man presented with acute onset of dysphagia following a meal which included octopus.
additional_history: He reported vomiting immediately after ingestion of food/liquid thereafter. A computed tomography scan was performed revealing esophageal dilation with obstruction by a hyperdense mass....Initial attempts at extracting or pushing of the food bolus was unsuccessful. Finally, the scope was maneuvered carefully past the food bolus into the stomach and retroflexed.
imaging_test_with_photo: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy performed showed an octopus lodged at the distal esophagus 5 cm from the cardio-esophageal junction (Figure-A).
next_imaging: A retrieval forceps was used to grasp the octopus head, gently pulling it into the stomach (Figure-B).
diagnosis: Octopus in the esophagus

context:
patient_presentation: A 60-year-old woman presented with chronic abdominal pain.
additional_history: The patient was of Caucasian origin, born in France, and had never traveled outside France. Initial endoscopic evaluation, with gastroscopy and colonoscopy, was normal. Gastroduodenal biopsies were also normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL, and ferritin 8 μg/L.
imaging_test_with_photo: The worm was found from the proximal jejunum, where young immature proglottids; consists of a chain of small segments wider than long; were visible (Figure A).
next_imaging: Then, the segments grow and stretch out gradually to become mature proglottids (Figure B).
third_imaging: This taenia was extended until the terminal ileum with gradual appearance of gravid proglottids, measuring about 20 mm long and 6 mm wide (Figures C and D). Mature and gravid proglottids are the reproductive structures of this hermaphrodite paraiste; with inside male and female structures. On our images some of these sexual structures are visible; in particular on the last gravid proglottids, with multiple lateral uterine branches (Figure C, blue arrow) and uterus (Figure D, black arrow). The parasite was visible on 75% of the transit time in the small bowel, estimating a size of 2 to 3 meters.
diagnosis: Small bowel capsule endoscopy (PillcamTM SB-III, Medtronic) diagnosed a Taenia saginata infection.

context:
patient_presentation: A 43-year-old woman, with an unremarkable medical history, was admitted for chronic diarrhea. 
imaging_without_photo: Colonoscopy was performed to evaluate the diarrhea.
imaging_test_with_photo: Perianal examination before the procedure revealed a 2.5 x 2 x 1.5-cm lesion extruding from the anus (Figure A) but reducible on digital examination. 
next_imaging: On top of the lesion was a 5-mm patch of a different appearing surface with a granular pattern (Figure B).
third_imaging: Subsequent colonoscopy was otherwise normal, although the polyp was confirmed on retroflexion (Figure C).

patient_presentation: A 60-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea for 9 months, anorexia, a 6-kg weight loss, and dysgeusia.
imaging_test_with_photo: He had hyperpigmentation of his face, hands (Figure A), and feet; alopecia; and nail dystrophy (Figure A).
next_imaging: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy and a colonoscopy showed multiple polyps carpeting the stomach, duodenum, ileum, and the colon (Figure B).
third_imaging: The patient's dysgeusia improved with zinc supplementation, he gained 8 kg of weight with eventual improvement in nail dystrophy (Figure C) and endoscopic resolution of the lesions (Figure D).
diagnosis: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome was diagnosed on the basis of clinical and pathologic findings. Investigations showed evidence of small intestinal bacteria overgrowth (a positive hydrogen breath test and jejunal aspirate growth of Klebsiella pneumoniae), hypothyroidism (thyroid-stimulating hormone, 94.65 ug/dL; normal, 0.27-4.2 ug/dL), and hypoalbuminemia (2.3 g/dL; normal, 3.5-5 g/dL).

context:
patient_presentation: A 79-year-old woman presented with intermittent abdominal pain, followed by nausea and hematochezia.
additional_history: Her history was significant for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) status post endovascular repair, coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass graft, aortic stenosis status post aortic valve replacement, and pulmonary fibrosis on home oxygen.
physical_exam: Physical examination showed tachycardia, hypotension, 
initial_laboratory_results: laboratory results were significant for a hemoglobin level of 5.5 g/dL.
imaging_test_with_photo: She was resuscitated, and a computed tomography scan (Figure A) showed intramural air within the aneurysm and fat stranding concerning for an acute rupture.
next_imaging: The patient was a poor surgical candidate, therefore, an endoscopy was performed to confirm a secondary aorto-enteric fistula (AEF) in the distal duodenum (Figure B).
diagnosis: ...a secondary aorot-enteric fistula (AEF) in the distal duodenum.

context:
patient_presentation: A 77-year-old woman with history of chronic kidney disease and hypertension presented to our hospital due to pneumonia. 
additional_history: She took calcium polystryene sulfonate (Kalimate) 30 g/d for hyperkalemia. Two weeks later, she developed melena. She denied nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs use.
initial_laboratory_results: A hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL was noted.
imaging_test_with_photo: She underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which showed multiple esophageal ulcers (Figure A)
next_imaging: She underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which showed...gastric ulcers (Figure B)
third_imaging: She underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which showed...duodenal ulcers (Figure C) with blood clots.
diagnosis: Thus, a diagnosis of Kalimate-induced esophageal, gastric, and duodenal ulcers was made.

context:
patient_presentation: An 88-year-old woman visited the Emergency Department for melena. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) findings showed a greater than 5-cm-diameter, pedunculated, subepithelial tumor with surface ulceration at the gastric fundus (Figure A). Although the forceps biopsy specimen indicated a histologically proven low-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), surgical resection was considered because of the large size and bleeding of the lesion. However, the patient refused surgery and subsequently was lost to follow-up evaluation.
next_imaging: After 3 months, the patient revisited the Emergency Department because of severe epigastric pain with vomiting. Computed tomography showed incarceration of the known gastric GIST into the duodenum. EGD confirmed the findings by computed tomography that the tumor was invaginated into the pyloric ring and its broad pedicle was drawn to the pylorus. The scope was inserted along the side of the incarcerated tumor into the pylorus, which enabled successful reduction of the tumor (Figure B; Movie 1) with subsequent improvement of symptoms.
diagnosis: Herein, we report a case of gastroduodenal intussusception caused by a huge pedunculated GIST located in the gastric fundus, which was managed by endoscopic reduction and subsequent surgery.

context:
patient_presentation: A 67-year-old man with a previous medical history of chronic obstructive bronchopneumopathy was evaluated for thoracic pain with cough associated with sputum, beginning 4 months previosuly.
physical_exam: Physical examination was normal.
imaging_test_with_photo: A chest radiograph showed elevation of the right diaphragmatic cupola (Figure A, yellow arrow).
next_imaging: A thoracoabdominal computed tomography showed right diaphragmatic eventration (Figure B, green arrow), with elevation of the right colic flexure (Figure B, blue arrows) and the liver, the latter everted such that the inferior aspect of the right lobe of the liver and the gallbladder now were located just beneath, the right hemidiaphragm (Figure B, red arrow).
diagnosis: We report a rare case of complete right diaphragmatic eventration as a result of atrophy of the diaphragmatic muscle fibers or phrenic paralysis.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old man presented at the emergency department with hematemesis.
additional_history: The symptoms started on the day of admission and patient had vomited four times a small amount of red blood. He did not complain of any abdominal pain or melena and was hemodynamically stable upon arrival. Patient was a heavy smoker with a history of non-malignant mediastinal lymphadenopathies, stroke, pacemaker implantation (sinus arrest and syncope), atrial fibrillation and intracranial hemorrhage under use of anticoagulants. Two weeks before admission, he underwent a left atrial appendage closure in order to stop anticoagulant use. His daily medication schedule consisted of acetylsalicylic acid, atorvastatin and bisoprolol.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory findings showed a normal hemoglobin (14.0 g/dL, reference 13.5-17.5 g/dL), normal liver tests and no inflammation.
imaging_test_with_photo: At the emergency department, pantoprazole was administered intravenously and patient received semi-urgent endoscopy. This revealed pale gastric mucosa with a large gastric ulcer at the incisura angularis and some smaller ulcers in the antrum (Fig. A), with stigmata of bleeding but without signs of active bleeding. Esophagus and duodenum were normal.
next_imaging: Arterial blood sample showed an increased lactate (6.7 mmol/L, reference 0.5-2.2 mmol/L) and an abdominal computed tomography (CT) was performed. This showed the presence of a foreign body in the aorta at the level of the superior mesenteric artery (Fig. B and C).
